description: Least m such that phi(m) = n!.
comments: Erdős believed (see Guy reference) that Phi[x] = n! is solvable.Factorial primes of p = A002981[m]!+1 = k!+1 form give smallest solutions for some m [like m = 1,2,3,11] as follows: Phi[p] = p-1 = A002981[m]!.According to Tattersall, in 1950 H. Gupta showed that phi(x) = n! is always solvable. - _Joseph L. Pe_, Oct 01 2002A123476(n) is a solution to the equation phi(x)=n! - _T. D. Noe_, Sep 27 2006Contribution from _M. F. Hasler_, Oct 04 2009: (Start)Conjecture: Unless n!+1 is prime (i.e., n in A002981), a(n)=pq where p is the least prime > sqrt(n!) such that (p-1) | n! and q=n!/(p-1)+1 is prime.Probably "least prime > sqrt(n!)" can also be replaced by "largest prime <= ceil(sqrt(n!))". The case "= ceil(...)" occurs for n=5, sqrt(120)=10.95..., p=11, q=13.a(n) is the first element in row n of the table A165773, which lists all solutions to phi(x)=n!. Thus a(n)=A165773(sum(A055506(k),k<n)+1). The last element of each row (i.e. the largest solution to phi(x)=n!) is given in A165774. (End)
references: P. Erdős and J. Lambek, Problem 4221, Amer. Math. Monthly, 55 (1948), 103.
R. K. Guy, (1981): Unsolved problems In Number Theory, Springer - page 53.
Tattersall, J., "Elementary Number Theory in Nine Chapters", Cambridge University Press, 2001, p. 162.
links: Max A. Alekseyev, Computing the (number of) inverses of Euler's totient and other multiplicative functions, arXiv preprint arXiv:1401.6054, 2014
prog: (PARI) A055487(n)={ my( f=n!, p=sqrtint(f)); isprime(f+1) && return(f+(n>1)); until( isprime(f/p+1), while( f%p=nextprime(p+2)-1,)); (p+1)*(f/p+1) } /* based on the conjecture */ \\ _M. F. Hasler_, Oct 04 2009
author: _Labos Elemer_, Jun 28 2000
extensions: More terms from Don Reble (djr(AT)nk.ca), Nov 05 2001
